YOU\'LL START OUT WITH SOMETHING LIKE THIS

Eighteen squares that each consist of four triangles that each have one of six different colors (red, green, blue, yellow, cyan or magenta). The nineteenth square (the one at the center) will always stay all-white.
YOUR GOAL IS TO ACHIEVE THIS

Turn all the eighteen squares (not counting the center-square) into single-color squares in the shortest amount of time. As long as you avoid triangle-crashes (explained next), the order of the squares is not important.

Two triangles of the same color must NEVER face each other like this. In other words: two triangles of the same color cannot share a square-border as their common baseline. If this happens, the game is lost.
Tap a square and release your finger. The square will then rotate in the direction of the arrows. From the start of a game, the rotation direction is clockwise (as shown here).
Tap the center-square and release your finger. The rotation direction (as shown by the arrows) will then change.

Tap a square, drag your finger to the center-square, and release it there. The square will then double-rotate. This is helpful if you cannot do two simple rotations (in either direction) without causing a triangle crash.
Tap a square, drag your finger to another square, and release it there. The two squares will then swap positions.
Tap the center-square, drag your finger to the border between two squares, and release it there. The two triangles on each side of that border will then swap positions.
REGRET WHATEVER YOU\'RE ABOUT TO DO
If you have tapped a square but not released your finger yet: just drag it outside of the entire figure and release it there. No move will then take place.
Finally, here\'s an example of a successful game.\nPlay with only one finger. It\'s best to use the thumb.\nNB: After fifty-nine minutes and fifty-nine seconds, the game is lost on time.

* The left column lists all of your games. The right column lists the top 100 of all games. You can click on the individual games in the two lists to view details about them.
 * Games are ranked firstly based on completed squares, secondly based on duration.
 * If all the eighteen squares are completed, the game's duration is simply the time elapsed until the game was finished.
 * If fewer than eighteen squares are completed, the game's duration is the time elapsed until the last completion of a square.
 (When you view a game move by move or with the Watch-feature, the text-color of the timer will be yellow when showing the game's duration.)
 * If no squares are completed, the game is not ranked.
